intro.description: Consume a SOAP Web Service by creating source and view models based on target WSDL file definition.

description.b: Follow steps below to create an ODA Web Service connection profile using the WSDL URL and end-point information.

subitem.label: Launch Create SOAP Connection Profile Wizard

subitem.description:
1) Enter WSDL URL (Local or remote)
2) Select Extract..., choose an end-point from your WSDL and click Next >
3) Choose one or more operations you wish to extract data from
4) Specify URL's to sample request and/or response documents
---- NOTE: These will be used later to help define your return data structure extract Inputs include: WSDL URL and sample request/response document XML files

description.b: This action utilizes the previously defined connection profile by interpreting the WSDL, locating any associated or dependent XML schema files, generating a physical model containing the required invoke procedures for the service, and generating virtual models containing procedures which will build and parse the XML declared as the service messages

subitem.label: Launch the Consume SOAP Web Service Wizard

subitem.description:
1) Select your connection profile and press Validate WSDL.
2) Set the target folder or project location and unique name for your generated source model. Click Next >.
3) For each operation, use your sample request or response XML document to define your view tables and corresponding generated SQL. Then click Next >.
4) Specify target location and unique name for your view model and click Finish.

description.b: Follow steps below to create a new VDB

subitem.description:
1) Select "..." button to browse and select project or folder location.
2) Enter a unique name for your VDB
3) Enter an optional description for your VDB
4) Select the Add button to choose models to go in your VDB
5) Click Finish

description.b: Follow steps below to create a new VDB

subitem.description:
1) Select "..." button to browse and select a VDB.
2) Click OK to deploy VDB and open connection in Data Source Explorer
3) Follow instructions in open SQL Scrapbook Editor
4) View your query results in the SQL Results view
